components.name: CheckboxIcon
components.description: A visual icon component representing the checked state of a checkbox, typically used within custom checkbox implementations to render the checkmark.

variants.description: Basic usage of the icon with custom coloring.
tips: Wrap in a container to set the background color.
Use className to override default fill colors.

variants.description: Interactive custom checkbox wrapper using the icon.
tips: Manage state in the parent wrapper component.
Conditionally render CheckboxIcon based on state.

variants.description: Accessible, keyboard-navigable checkbox with focus states.
tips: Use forwardRef to allow parent focus management.
Implement ARIA attributes (role, aria-checked) for accessibility.
Handle 'Enter' and 'Space' keys for keyboard interaction.

components.stylingNotes: The icon inherits color from the 'text-' utility classes in Tailwind. Ensure the container has a defined width/height to prevent layout shifts.
commonMistakes: Forgetting to conditionally render the icon when unchecked.
Not adding keyboard event handlers for accessibility.

components.name: EmptyStateIcon
components.description: A graphical icon designed for empty states, providing a consistent visual cue when content is absent, such as no search results or zero balance.

variants.description: Basic rendering of the icon with size adjustments.
tips: Use Tailwind width/height classes to scale the icon.
Apply opacity to make it subtler.

variants.description: Standard empty state layout with title and description.
tips: Pair with descriptive text to explain the empty state.
Add subtle background effects for a polished look.

variants.description: Conditional rendering based on portfolio data using hooks.
tips: Use hooks like useAccountInfo to determine if the state is truly empty.
Provide a Call-to-Action (CTA) button to guide the user out of the empty state.

components.stylingNotes: The icon is monochrome. Use 'text-gray-500' or similar for a neutral look, or brand colors if the empty state is positive (e.g., 'All Clear').
commonMistakes: Showing the empty state while data is still loading (check loading states first).
Using the icon without explanatory text, leaving users confused.

components.name: InputPrefix
components.description: A layout wrapper that positions content (icons, labels, or selectors) at the start of an input field, ensuring consistent alignment and spacing.

variants.description: Basic usage with an icon
tips: Use absolute positioning on the InputPrefix wrapper to align it perfectly within the relative input container.
Add padding-left (pl-*) to the Input equal to the prefix width to prevent text overlap.

variants.description: Text label prefix for context
tips: Text prefixes are great for currency symbols or fixed units.
Ensure the font weight of the prefix matches the input text for a cohesive look.

variants.description: Interactive token selector prefix
tips: You can make the prefix clickable to trigger a token selection modal.
Use background colors on the prefix to visually distinguish it from the editable input area.

components.stylingNotes: InputPrefix typically requires absolute positioning (left-0 or left-3) and vertical centering (top-1/2 -translate-y-1/2) to sit correctly inside a relative Input container.
commonMistakes: Forgetting to add padding-left to the Input element, causing user text to overlap the prefix.
Not setting the parent container to 'relative', causing the prefix to flow outside the input bounds.

components.name: InputSuffix
components.description: A layout wrapper that positions content at the end of an input field, commonly used for currency symbols, 'Max' buttons, or balance displays.

variants.description: Static currency label
tips: Align input text to the right (text-right) when using a suffix for better readability of numbers.
Ensure padding-right (pr-*) on the Input accommodates the suffix width.

variants.description: Action button (Max/Clear)
tips: Use conditional rendering to switch between 'Max' and 'Clear' actions based on input state.
Style buttons with transparent backgrounds to blend seamlessly with the input.

variants.description: Balance display with Max action
tips: Integrate with useAccountInfo to fetch real-time available balance for the suffix.
Use a monospace font for the input if displaying financial data to align decimal points.

components.stylingNotes: InputSuffix requires absolute positioning (right-0 or right-3) and vertical centering. Ensure z-index is handled if the suffix contains interactive elements like dropdowns.
commonMistakes: Suffix content overflowing the input container on small screens.
Not adding enough padding-right to the Input, causing the cursor to disappear behind the suffix while typing.

components.name: TextField
components.description: A standard text input wrapper combining a label, input field, and error handling, designed for form consistency.

variants.description: Basic usage with controlled state
tips: Always use `onValueChange` instead of standard `onChange` for consistency.
The component automatically handles basic input styling.

variants.description: Input with error handling and suffix
tips: Use the `error` prop to automatically display red borders and text.
Combine with `InputSuffix` to denote currency or units.

variants.description: Full-featured input with prefix, suffix, and validation
tips: Use `InputPrefix` for icons or fixed symbols like 'x' for leverage.
Ensure unique `id` props are passed for accessibility (label association).

components.stylingNotes: The TextField uses CSS variables for colors. You can override `--orderly-input-bg` or `--orderly-input-border` to match your theme. The label font size is fixed but can be adjusted via utility classes on the label element if you clone the component.
commonMistakes: Using `onChange` instead of `onValueChange` which expects a string value directly.
Forgetting to handle the `error` prop state, leading to stale error messages.

components.name: ExtensionProvider
components.description: A React Context provider that enables the plugin/extension system, allowing dynamic UI injection via ExtensionSlots.

variants.description: Basic provider setup
tips: Wrap this provider at the root of your application, ideally inside other Orderly providers.
Without this provider, `ExtensionSlot` components will not render anything.

variants.description: Registering custom extensions
tips: The `extensions` prop is an object where keys are slot names and values are React components.
Extensions can be dynamically added or removed by updating the prop.

variants.description: Complex extension system with props and context
tips: Extensions defined in the registry can access React Context if they are rendered within the provider tree.
Use this pattern to allow third-party plugins to inject UI into specific 'safe zones' of your app.

components.stylingNotes: The ExtensionProvider itself does not render DOM nodes, so it has no styles. Focus styling on the components returned by your extension registry.
commonMistakes: Defining extensions inside the render function of the parent component, causing unnecessary re-renders.
Trying to use `ExtensionSlot` outside of the `ExtensionProvider` tree.

components.name: ExtensionSlot
components.description: A placeholder component that renders registered extensions (plugins) at specific, predefined positions within the UI, allowing for dynamic content injection.

variants.description: Basic usage of a slot at a predefined position.
tips: Ensure the component is wrapped in an ExtensionProvider.
Use ExtensionPositionEnum to avoid typos in position strings.

variants.description: Slot wrapped in a provider with a mock plugin registration.
tips: Plugins must follow the structure { name, extensions: [{ position, Component }] }.
Multiple plugins can register to the same position.

variants.description: Slot rendering plugins that utilize internal hooks for data.
tips: Extensions act as standard React components and can use hooks.
Ensure the Provider is high enough in the tree to provide context for hooks used in extensions.

components.stylingNotes: ExtensionSlot itself is usually invisible (display: contents or block wrapper). Style the injected Component within the plugin definition.
commonMistakes: Forgetting to wrap the app in ExtensionProvider.
Using incorrect position strings that don't match the enum.

components.name: CombineSelect
components.description: A compact select component combining a trigger and dropdown, designed for small footprints like asset or timeframe selection.

variants.description: Simple string selection with minimal configuration.
tips: The 'xs' size is default for this component to fit tight UI spaces.
Options can be a simple array of strings.

variants.description: Object-based options with custom rendering for values.
tips: Use renderValue to format the selected item differently from the list items.
Ensure the value passed to onValueChange matches the option value type.

variants.description: Integrated with useOrderEntry to control trading symbol.
tips: Combine className and popperClassName to match dark/light themes.
Integrate directly with state management hooks for real-time updates.

components.stylingNotes: Use the 'size' prop to control density. Pass 'className' to style the trigger button and 'popperClassName' for the dropdown menu.
commonMistakes: Passing objects as options without defining how to render them (label/value).
Not handling the onChange event to update parent state.

components.name: TokenSelect
components.description: A specialized dropdown for selecting cryptocurrency tokens with built-in search and display logic.

variants.description: Basic token selection with a static list.
tips: Ensure your token objects include a 'symbol' property for display.
The 'value' prop should match the symbol of the selected token.

variants.description: Searchable dropdown with custom placeholder and disabled state handling.
tips: Enable 'searchable' to allow users to filter the list by typing.
You can disable the input by passing the 'disabled' prop.

variants.description: Integration with chain context and account balance display.
tips: Use 'renderToken' to customize the list items, e.g., showing balances.
Filter tokens based on the active chain using 'useChain' to prevent invalid selections.

components.stylingNotes: TokenSelect usually has a fixed width. Ensure the parent container allows for the dropdown list to expand vertically without being clipped by 'overflow: hidden'.
commonMistakes: Passing a token object to 'value' instead of the token symbol string.
Forgetting to handle the case where the token list is empty or loading.

components.name: SliderTip
components.description: A tooltip component that tracks and displays the value of a range slider thumb.

variants.description: Simple slider with a tooltip displaying the raw value.
tips: Wrap your input[type='range'] with SliderTip.
The 'value' prop must be synchronized with the input's value.

variants.description: Formatted tooltip with percentage display and custom styling.
tips: Use the 'formatter' prop to convert raw numbers into readable strings (e.g., percentages or currency).
Apply custom classes to the tooltip via the 'className' prop to match your theme.

variants.description: Integration with order entry logic to set position size percentage.
tips: Connect the slider onChange event to 'useOrderEntry' actions for dynamic order sizing.
Ensure the calculation logic handles floating point precision correctly.

components.stylingNotes: The SliderTip positions itself absolutely. Ensure the parent container has 'position: relative' if you encounter layout issues. The tooltip arrow color may need to match your background.
commonMistakes: Not updating the 'value' prop when the input changes, causing the tooltip to desync.
Placing the SliderTip wrapper around a div instead of the input element directly.

components.name: DataFilter
components.description: A UI component for filtering data sets, typically rendered as a segmented control or tab bar to switch between views.

variants.description: Basic usage with static string options.
tips: Ensure the value passed matches the option value exactly.
Use for simple view toggling.

variants.description: Controlled component with custom styling and icons.
tips: Pass an icon property to options for better UX.
Use the variant prop to change shape (e.g., 'pill', 'underline').

variants.description: Integrated with useOrderStore to filter order data.
tips: Connect directly to state management hooks for real-time filtering.
Ensure types match the expected values from your store.

components.stylingNotes: DataFilter usually supports variants like 'default', 'pill', or 'underline'. Use className to override background colors for dark mode compatibility.
commonMistakes: Using non-string values for options without a custom key extractor.
Forgetting to lift state up when the filter needs to affect sibling components.

components.name: DataTable
components.description: A comprehensive table component that handles data rendering, loading states, and empty states for structured financial data.

variants.description: Static data rendering with basic columns.
tips: Define columns with 'header' and 'accessor' keys.
Data array should be an array of objects.

variants.description: Dynamic data with loading and empty states.
tips: Utilize isLoading to show a skeleton loader.
Provide a custom emptyMessage for better UX.

variants.description: Integrated with useOrderEntity for real-time order management.
tips: Use the 'cell' property in columns for custom rendering (e.g., buttons or colored text).
Combine with useOrderStore to trigger actions like canceling directly from the table.

components.stylingNotes: DataTable is responsive by default. You can pass custom class names to the container or specific rows. Ensure z-index is handled if using sticky headers.
commonMistakes: Mutating the data array directly instead of using the hook's state.
Forgetting to handle the 'isLoading' state resulting in layout shifts.

components.name: TableBody
components.description: The body section of the DataTable that iterates over data to render rows, handling row-specific styles and layout.

variants.description: Basic iteration over static data
tips: Ensure unique keys are provided for each row.
Wrap in a DataTable for consistent styling.

variants.description: Integration with Order Entity hook
tips: Use the TableCell component for consistent padding and alignment.
Handle empty states gracefully.

variants.description: Interactive rows with conditional styling
tips: Add hover states to improve UX.
Use conditional classes to highlight specific row statuses.

components.stylingNotes: TableBody relies on standard HTML table elements. Use Tailwind classes like `border-b`, `p-4`, and `text-sm` on child `tr` or `td` elements to match the Orderly design system.
commonMistakes: Forgetting to handle the loading or empty state of the data array.
Mixing `div` elements directly inside TableBody instead of `tr` and `td`.

components.name: TableCell
components.description: A low-level component for rendering individual data cells, handling content alignment and basic formatting.

variants.description: Simple text rendering
tips: Use for simple string or number display.
Inherits font settings from parent table styles.

variants.description: Alignment and formatting
tips: Use the `align` prop ('left', 'right', 'center') for numeric columns.
Combine with spans for sub-labels.

variants.description: PnL formatting and conditional styling
tips: Use `NumTypePnl` for automatic coloring of profit/loss values.
Embed icons or status indicators inside TableCell for rich data display.

components.stylingNotes: TableCell provides default padding. Override using Tailwind utility classes (e.g., `py-2`, `px-4`) if custom spacing is needed. Ensure text colors contrast well with the table background.
commonMistakes: Hardcoding alignment instead of using the `align` prop.
Wrapping TableCell in a div, which breaks table layout semantics.

components.name: NumTypeRoi
components.description: A typography component that automatically color-codes Return on Investment (ROI) figures based on positive, negative, or zero values.

variants.description: Basic usage with static positive, negative, and zero values.
tips: Pass a float (e.g., 0.15 for 15%) rather than a percentage string.
The component handles the color logic automatically based on the sign.

variants.description: Configuring decimal places and displaying percentage signs.
tips: Use the `options` prop to control formatting like `decimals` and `suffix`.
Ensure the parent container has enough width to prevent layout shifts.

variants.description: Integrating with account data hooks to display real-time portfolio ROI.
tips: Combine with `useAccountInfo` to derive ROI metrics from equity changes.
Handle loading states gracefully while hooks fetch data.

components.stylingNotes: The component uses CSS variables for colors (e.g., `var(--orderly-colors-positive)`). You can override these variables in your global CSS to match your theme's specific green/red shades.
commonMistakes: Passing a string percentage (e.g., '15%') instead of a float (0.15).
Forgetting to handle `null` or `undefined` values which can cause rendering errors.

components.name: NumTypePnl
components.description: A specialized typography component for displaying Profit and Loss (PnL) values with currency formatting and semantic coloring.

variants.description: Displaying static PnL values for profit and loss scenarios.
tips: The component automatically adds the currency symbol (usually $).
Colors are semantic: Green for positive, Red for negative.

variants.description: Using PnL in a list of positions with specific decimal formatting.
tips: Use the `options` prop to standardize decimal precision across tables.
Zero values typically render in a neutral color (gray/white).

variants.description: Fetching order details and displaying the resulting PnL using hooks.
tips: Integrate with `useOrderEntity` to show PnL for specific historical orders.
Always check if the order data exists before accessing PnL properties to avoid crashes.

components.stylingNotes: NumTypePnl inherits font settings from the parent. Ensure the parent has a defined font size if you want to scale the PnL text up or down.
commonMistakes: Passing a string representation of currency (e.g., '$500') instead of a number.
Assuming the component converts units (e.g., cents to dollars); it formats the number passed to it.

components.name: NumTypeNotional
components.description: A typography component designed to display notional values (total value of positions/contracts), handling large financial figures and currency symbols.

variants.description: Basic usage with static value
tips: Always pass the symbol prop to ensure correct currency formatting.
The value prop expects a number, not a string.

variants.description: Dynamic calculation from position data
tips: Use this component when displaying the total dollar value of a position.
It automatically scales numbers (e.g., $21k) if space is constrained or based on config.

variants.description: Integration with position list and error handling
tips: Ideal for use in Portfolio or Positions tables.
Ensure the symbol string matches the Orderly symbol format exactly.

components.stylingNotes: The component renders a span or text element. You can pass standard Tailwind classes (like text-xl, font-mono) via the className prop to align it with your design system.
commonMistakes: Passing the raw position size instead of the calculated notional (size * price).
Forgetting to pass the 'symbol' prop, resulting in missing currency formatting.

components.name: NumTypeAssetValue
components.description: A specialized typography component for displaying asset values like wallet balances, ensuring correct decimal places for crypto assets.

variants.description: Displaying a static wallet balance
tips: Use this for specific asset quantities, not total portfolio value.
It respects the decimal precision rules of the specific asset.

variants.description: Displaying multiple asset balances
tips: This component is perfect for the 'Assets' tab in a wallet view.
It handles the difference between high-precision assets (like ETH) and stablecoins.

variants.description: Asset list with value estimation and status
tips: Combine with price data to show estimated USD value alongside the raw asset amount.
Use font-mono for the value to prevent layout shift when numbers change.

components.stylingNotes: Outputs a standard span element. Use flex utilities to align labels and values. The font color usually defaults to the current text color.
commonMistakes: Using this component to display Notional values (use NumTypeNotional instead).
Passing a string representation of a number which may cause formatting errors.

components.name: NumTypeCollateral
components.description: Typography component specialized for formatting and displaying collateral values, typically used for margin and equity metrics.

variants.description: Basic usage with a static value to demonstrate formatting.
tips: Use this component whenever displaying monetary values related to margin to ensure consistent formatting.
It automatically handles decimal places based on the token context if provided, or defaults to USD formatting.

variants.description: Integrates with useMarginAccount to display real-time user collateral.
tips: Always handle the isLoading state from useMarginAccount to prevent layout shifts.
Fallback to 0 if data is undefined to avoid rendering errors during initial load.

variants.description: Displays multiple collateral metrics with conditional styling based on health.
tips: Combine with NumTypeAssetValue to show the breakdown of specific assets contributing to collateral.
Use the health factor logic to trigger visual warnings for users approaching liquidation.

components.stylingNotes: NumTypeCollateral renders a span or text element. Apply font weights and colors to the parent container or the component itself via className to match your design system.
commonMistakes: Passing a string value instead of a number; ensure you parse API responses if necessary.
Forgetting to handle undefined data during the initial fetch, which can cause NaN display.

components.name: AuthGuard
components.description: A conditional wrapper that renders children only if the user is authenticated, otherwise prompting connection.

variants.description: Protects a simple action button.
tips: AuthGuard automatically handles the 'Connect Wallet' UI logic for you.
Place it as close to the protected UI elements as possible to keep the code readable.

variants.description: Protects a complex trading form component.
tips: Use this to wrap entire sections of your dashboard (like Portfolio or History) to prevent unauthorized access.
The default fallback is a styled button, but it can be customized via props if needed.

variants.description: Combines AuthGuard with AuthGuardEmpty for a custom empty state and checks account status.
tips: Use the 'empty' prop to pass AuthGuardEmpty or a custom component for a consistent UI when the user is logged out.
Combine with useAccountInfo inside the children to ensure the user has a valid trading account, not just a connected wallet.

components.stylingNotes: AuthGuard renders a div wrapper. The default Connect Wallet button uses Orderly's default styles. Use the 'empty' prop to inject a fully custom styled login area that matches your app's theme.
commonMistakes: Nesting AuthGuards unnecessarily; one guard at the top level of a route or section is usually sufficient.
Assuming AuthGuard checks for a *valid* Orderly Key; it only checks wallet connection. Use useAccountInfo for deeper validation.

components.name: AuthGuardEmpty
components.description: Conditionally renders children only if the user is authenticated, rendering nothing (null) if not, effectively hiding protected UI elements without prompts.

variants.description: Basic usage to hide a text element based on auth status.
tips: Use this to hide specific UI elements (like 'Deposit' buttons) instead of blocking the whole page.
It does not show any modal or loading spinner by default.

variants.description: Hides a user profile section that displays account details.
tips: Combine with useAccount to access user details inside the protected tree.
The component handles the conditional rendering logic internally.

variants.description: Protects a complex trading interface that requires API keys and account data.
tips: Ideal for dashboards where public and private data coexist.
Ensure children handle their own loading states for data fetching.

components.stylingNotes: Since it renders nothing when unauthenticated, ensure the parent layout handles the absence of content gracefully (e.g., using flexbox or grid) so the layout doesn't break or collapse unexpectedly.
commonMistakes: Using it for the main page entry point (use AuthGuard instead to prompt login).
Expecting it to show a loading spinner while checking auth (it renders null immediately).

components.name: WalletConnectorWidget

components.name: EffectiveFeesWidget
